p: Influenza A virus (IAV) infection affects about 20% of the worldwide population annually [ 1]. The 2009 influenza pandemic showed that the next pandemic could cause major adverse health and economic outcomes [ 2]. While vaccines remain the primary means to prevent outbreaks, the effects of influenza vaccines are mild and regularly outpaced by the antigenic drift of the virus [ 3]. As a result, stockpiling antiviral drugs in anticipation of a pandemic has been recommended, among other public health routines [ 4]. The benefits of this approach, however, have been debated in terms of treating and preventing epidemic spread [ 5, 6].
